name: EEG Neurofeedback
summary: A non-invasive brain training method using real-time EEG feedback to help individuals learn to regulate their brain activity, applied in ADHD, anxiety, epilepsy, and other conditions.
description:
EEG neurofeedback, also called EEG biofeedback or neurotherapy, uses electroencephalography (EEG) to measure brainwave activity and provides real-time feedback to the participant, often through visual or auditory cues. The participant learns to increase or decrease certain brainwave patterns associated with improved cognitive or emotional functioning.

It is used both as a therapeutic intervention for clinical conditions and as a performance enhancement tool. Protocols are tailored to the individual's EEG profile and treatment goals, and sessions are typically repeated over several weeks.

delivery_methods: EEG sensors with computer feedback system

contraindications: Severe intellectual disability without capacity for training
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally well-tolerated; occasional transient fatigue, headache, or increased anxiety.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate for ADHD and epilepsy; limited or emerging for other conditions.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Several controlled trials for ADHD; mixed evidence for other uses.

sections.text: EEG neurofeedback trains individuals to modify brainwave activity through operant conditioning, rewarding desired EEG patterns (e.g., increased sensorimotor rhythm, reduced theta/beta ratio) that correlate with improved cognitive or emotional states.

sections.preparation: Baseline EEG recording and symptom assessment to identify target patterns.
procedure: Placement of EEG electrodes on scalp.
Measurement of brainwave activity in real-time.
Delivery of visual/auditory feedback contingent on brainwave changes.
Gradual shaping of target EEG patterns over repeated sessions.

sections.pre_session: Review of progress and symptoms; electrode placement.
sections.post_session: Discussion of session performance and symptom tracking.

uncommon: Increased anxiety at start of training

absolute: Inability to engage in training exercises

ideal_candidates: Motivated individuals able to attend multiple sessions

practitioner: Licensed clinician trained in neurofeedback protocols
facility: Clinic equipped with EEG and neurofeedback systems

studies: Arns M, et al. Efficacy of neurofeedback treatment in ADHD: the effects on inattention, impulsivity, and hyperactivity: a meta-analysis. Clin EEG Neurosci. 2009;40(3):180–189.
Tan G, et al. Efficacy of EEG biofeedback in treating epilepsy. Appl Psychophysiol Biofeedback. 2009;34(3):211–227.
sections.limitations: Variable protocol quality across studies; placebo effects possible.

sections.cost_effectiveness: Potentially cost-effective for ADHD in motivated patients

lifestyle_recommendations: Regular practice of relaxation and focus exercises

sections.children: Commonly used for ADHD; protocols adapted for developmental level.
sections.elderly: May benefit for cognitive rehabilitation post-stroke.
sections.comorbidities: Screen for seizure risk before initiation.

items: Effectiveness depends on protocol quality and adherence.
May serve as adjunct to medication or behavioral therapy.
Requires trained practitioner for interpretation and protocol adjustment.
